title-group.article-title: Antenatal maternal protein deprivation: sexually dimorphic programming of the pancreatic renin-angiotensin system

contrib-group.aff: Center for Perinatal Biology, School of Medicine, Loma Linda University, USA

author-notes.corresp: Ravi Goyal, Center for Perinatal Biology, Loma Linda University, School of Medicine, Loma Linda, CA 92350, USA. Email: rgoyal@llu.edu

abstract.p: As an underlying mechanism of antenatal maternal malnutrition-induced type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), alterations in the local pancreatic renin-angiotensin system (RAS) may play a significant role. We tested the hypothesis that antenatal maternal protein deprivation (AMPD) leads to increased activity of the local pancreatic RAS, with associated hyperglycemia in the adult progeny. Mice dams were fed either control or 50% protein restricted diet (AMPD) starting one week before conception and maintained during complete gestation. Our results demonstrate low birth weight (control 1.5 ± 0.03 and AMPD 1.3 ± 0.03) and sexually dimorphic programming of the pancreatic RAS, with development of hyperglycemia only in the female mice offspring as a consequence of AMPD. No significant difference in serum insulin concentration was observed; however, AMPD was associated with increased mRNA and protein expression of angiotensinogen, renin and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE)-1 in male and female offspring. Of importance, mRNA and protein expression of ACE 2 and angiotensin II receptors was up-regulated only in the male offspring, as a consequence of AMPD. We conclude that sexually dimorphic programming of the pancreatic RAS expression is associated with AMPD diet-mediated development of hyperglycemia.

kwd-group.kwd: developmental origins of adult health and disease

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) constitutes a serious health problem in the USA and many other parts of the world,1 and its prevalence is steadily increasing among the adult and young population (National Diabetes Fact Sheet, 2011). During the past several decades, a number of important risk factors have been associated with T2DM. These include: sedentary lifestyle, high body mass index, smoking cigarettes and others. Nonetheless, many individuals who develop T2DM do not have these risk factors. Thus, it is clear that, as yet, unrecognized and under-appreciated factors must be considered in the genesis of T2DM. Moreover, epidemiological studies and experiments in laboratory animals have suggested that antenatal maternal malnutrition may be a major causative factor in the genesis of T2DM. Along this line, a factor that has received increasing attention is the idea of “programming” during fetal life, often as a consequence of maternal stress.2 The concept of Developmental Origins of Health and Disease (DOHaD) has emerged as an important risk factor during the past few decades. Initially, DOHaD was associated with coronary artery disease and hypertension,3 however, other chronic disorders such as T2DM also have been linked with the programming.2 Moreover, experiments in laboratory animals have shown that antenatal maternal low-caloric/protein diet can lead to the development of programming (origin) of insulin resistance and T2DM in adult offspring.4,5

Another concept with regard to T2DM is that of dysregulation of the renin-angiotensin system (RAS).6,7 Of vital importance, the RAS exists not only as a systemic pathway,8 but also as a whole in various tissues and organ systems that function independently.9–12 In addition, studies have demonstrated conclusively that RAS plays an important role in the regulation of blood glucose.6,7,13 Taken together, a considerable body of evidence suggests that T2DM can be programmed by antenatal maternal malnutrition. Studies also indicate that the RAS plays an important role in the manifestation of T2DM. However, the extent to which antenatal maternal protein deprivation (AMPD) is associated with alterations in the expression of the pancreatic RAS components, which may be responsible for the development of T2DM in adult life of the offspring, is not known. Thus, we tested the hypothesis that AMPD leads to increased expression of the pancreatic RAS, which may lead to T2DM.

sec.title: Experimental animal and tissues
sec.p: The present study was in compliance with the Animal Welfare Act and approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC) of Loma Linda University. Studies were conducted on FVB/NJ Mice, a strain chosen because their fertilized eggs contain prominent pronuclei, which will be of value in future transgenic studies. We obtained mice (~eight weeks of age) from Jackson Laboratories (Bar Harbor, ME), and housed them at the Animal Research Facility, Loma Linda University, under conditions of 14 hours’ light, 10 hours’ darkness, ambient temperature of 20°C and relative humidity of 30% to 60%. At 16 weeks of age, the mice were bred by keeping the males and females together for 12 hours (overnight). In the morning, mating was confirmed by examination of vaginal plugs and considered 0.5 day post coitum (DPC).

sec.title: Protein deprivation
sec.p: Protein-restricted chow was obtained from Newco Distributors Inc (Rancho Cucamonga, CA). Mice dams were divided in two groups: control protein diet (18 g/100 g, 100% protein content), and AMPD (9 g/100 g, 50% protein diet). To avoid the stress of food change and include the peri-conceptual period, diet administration was commenced one week before mating. We replaced protein with carbohydrates so that the diet was isocaloric. The exact compositions of the diets administered are given in supplemental Tables 1 and 2. The normal diet contained 18 g protein/100 g food, as described by guidelines published by Nutrient Requirements of Laboratory Animals, Fourth Revised Edition, 1995 (Washington, DC, National Academy Press, 1995). We measured the amounts of food (g/day) consumed by the mice on normal diet and isocaloric low-protein diets. The amounts of food (g/day) consumed by the mice on the normal diet and the isocaloric low-protein diets were similar, being 3±0.5 g for females (n=16) and 4±0.3 g for males (n=16) in the control group and 3±0.4 (n=16) for females and 4±0.34 g for males (n=16) in the AMPD group.

fn.p: AGT: angiotensinogen; ACE: angiotensin-converting enzyme; GAPDH: glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase.

sec.title: mRNA and protein quantification
sec.p: Real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was conducted, as described and validated previously by our laboratory.9,10,14 At three weeks of age, mice were sacrificed by cervical dislocation and pancreas was dissected out. We isolated and quantified RNA and protein by Allprep DNA/RNA Mini Kit according to the manufacturer’s instructions (Qiagen Inc, Cat # 80204). The 260/280 ratio of 1.8 to 2 was accepted for quantification with real-time PCR. The mRNA was reverse-transcribed using Quantitect RT Kit (Qiagen Inc). Real-time PCR was performed on Light Cycler 1.5 (Roche Inc, Indianapolis, IN) using hydrolysis TaqMan probes and primers (Table 1), designed using the Universal Probe Library, a web-based software (Roche Inc), and the Quantifast PCR master-mix (Qiagen Inc). Cycles required (based on initial mRNA of a particular gene) to reach a threshold detection limit by the real-time PCR were recorded and normalized to a housekeeping gene (18 S ribosomal RNA). We determined the -fold changes with the ΔΔCT method15 after performing validation curves.

For protein estimation we conducted a modified enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) using nitrocellulose-blotting membrane, as described previously.16,17 Briefly, frozen samples were homogenized in the 1 × cell lysing buffer (Cell Signaling Technology, Beverly, MA) containing 1× phosphatase and protease inhibitors cocktail (Sigma). Protein concentration was determined using Bio-Rad Protein Assay (Biorad Laboratories, Hercules, CA). Protein (4 µg from each sample) was loaded on a nitrocellulose bottom 96-well plate (Millipore Corp, Bedford, MA) and blocked for one hour by adding 100 μl of 5% non-fat milk blocking solution. We then incubated the wells with primary antibody and then secondary antibodies diluted in 5% non-fat milk blocking solution at room temperature with rocking. Protein concentration was detected with infrared scanner Odyssey (Licor). Analysis was done by NIH ImageJ analysis software.

sec.title: Blood glucose and insulin measurement
sec.p: Random blood glucose levels were measured by obtaining blood from the left ventricle at time of sacrifice following the Jackson Laboratory Protocol. Briefly, 1 µl of blood was applied on the test strip for Johnson and Johnson’s OneTouch® Ultra Blood Glucose Monitoring System (http://jaxmice.jax.org/diomice/diomice-phenotypes.html). Calibration of the OneTouch® Ultra Blood Glucose Monitoring System was performed using control test solutions provided by the manufacturer (Lifescan Inc, Milpitas, CA). Serum insulin levels were measured utilizing commercially available ELISA kits (Alpco Distributors, Salem, NH), according to the manufacturer’s instructions.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: To determine significant differences between groups, we analyzed the data using unpaired, two-tailed Student’s t-test by the use of GraphPad Prism software (GraphPad Software Inc, San Diego, CA). The hypothesis was accepted at p<0.05. For each experiment, n equaled to four or more, as noted.

sec.title: Maternal low-protein diet and low birth weight
sec.p: In males and females, AMPD was associated with a significant reduction in the birth weight (Figure 1A), being (g) 1.496 ± 0.04 (n=8), 1.294 ± 0.04 (n=11), 1.56 ± 0.05 (n=8), 1.232 ± 0.04 (n=11) for control male, AMPD male, control female and AMPD female, respectively. The placental weights and litter size did not differ significantly. Of importance, there was a rapid catch-up growth in the AMPD offspring so that by four weeks of age there was no significant difference in body weights of the two groups.

caption.p: Effect of antenatal maternal low-protein diet (AMPD) on birth weight and blood glucose (A) birth weight, (B) random blood glucose levels (mg/dl), (C) serum insulin of offspring from control mice dams and those receiving AMPD. *Denotes p-value < 0.05 on two-tailed unpaired Student’s t-test. N = 5 for each group.

sec.title: Maternal low-protein diet and blood glucose levels
sec.p: Our results also demonstrate that there was a significant increase (~25%; p < 0.05) in the random blood glucose levels in the female offspring of AMPD group (Figure 1B). In contrast, no change in random blood glucose was observed in AMPD male offspring. Also, the serum insulin levels did not differ significantly in either sex (Figure 1C).

sec.title: AMPD and pancreatic angiotensinogen (AGT) expression
sec.p: Both angiotensinogen mRNA and protein were expressed in the pancreas locally. Importantly, as a consequence of AMPD, AGT mRNA (Figure 2A) and protein expression levels (Figure 2B) were significantly higher, as compared to control.

caption.p: Antenatal maternal low-protein diet (AMPD) and angiotensinogen (AGT) expression in pancreas. (A) Relative fold-change in angiotensinogen mRNA levels in control and AMPD males and females offspring. (B) Relative integrated density values (IDV; arbitrary units) of AGT protein levels in control and AMPD males and females offspring. *Denotes p-value < 0.05 on two-tailed unpaired Student’s t-test. N = 5 for each group.

sec.title: AMPD and pancreatic renin expression
sec.p: Renin protein also was detectable locally in the murine pancreas; however, with quantitative real-time PCR techniques, we were unable to detect renin mRNA (kidneys were used as a positive control). Of interest, as a consequence of AMPD, in the pancreas from both sexes we observed a significant increase (25% to 40% in renin protein levels (Figure 3)).

caption.p: Antenatal maternal low-protein diet (AMPD) and renin protein expression in pancreas. *Denotes p-value < 0.05 on two-tailed unpaired Student’s t-test. N = 5 for each group.

sec.title: AMPD and pancreatic angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) expression
sec.p: Both ACE-1 and -2 were expressed locally in the pancreas. Moreover, the ACE-1 mRNA (Figure 4A) and protein levels (Figure 4B) were significantly higher in the pancreas from male and female offspring, as a consequence of AMPD. However, as a consequence of AMPD, we observed in male offspring only an increase in ACE-2 mRNA (Figure 6A) and protein levels (Figure 6B).

caption.p: Antenatal maternal low-protein diet (AMPD) and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) expression in the pancreas. (A) Relative fold-change in ACE1 mRNA levels in control and AMPD males and females offspring. (B) Relative integrated density values (IDV) of ACE-1 protein levels in control and AMPD males and females offspring. *Denotes p-value < 0.05 on two-tailed unpaired Student’s t-test. N = 5 for each group.

sec.title: AMPD and pancreatic angiotensin II levels
sec.p: Angiotensin II levels were significantly higher in the male and female pancreas from the AMPD groups (Figure 5).

caption.p: Antenatal maternal low-protein diet (AMPD) and angiotensin II levels in the pancreas. *Denotes p-value < 0.05 on two-tailed unpaired Student’s t-test. N = 5 for each group.

Antenatal maternal low-protein diet (AMPD) and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE)-2 expression. (A) Relative fold-change in ACE2 mRNA levels in control and AMPD males and females offspring. (B) Relative integrated density values (IDV) of ACE2 protein levels in control and AMPD males and females offspring. *Denotes p-value < 0.05 on two-tailed unpaired Student’s t-test. N = 5 for each group.

sec.title: AMPD and pancreatic angiotensin II receptor expression
sec.p: Two AT-1 receptors transcripts are known to exist in mice, AT-1a and AT-1b, and both were present in the pancreas (Figure 7A and 7B). However, no change in AT1a receptors mRNA or AT1 protein expression was observed in either the male or female pancreas as a consequence of AMPD (Figure 7C). Furthermore, AT-2 receptor also was detectable at both the mRNA and protein level in the pancreas (Figure 8). Of importance, both AT2 receptors mRNA (Figure 8A) and protein (Figure 8B) were significantly increased in the male pancreas as a consequence of AMPD.

caption.p: Antenatal maternal low-protein diet (AMPD) and angiotensin II type I receptor expression. (A and B) Relative fold-change in AT1a and AT1b receptors mRNA levels in control and AMPD males and females offspring, respectively. (C) Relative integrated density values (IDV) of AT1 receptors protein levels in control and AMPD males and females offspring. *Denotes p-value < 0.05 on two-tailed unpaired Student’s t-test. N = 5 for each group.

Antenatal maternal low-protein diet (AMPD) and angiotensin II type II receptor expression. (A) Relative fold-change in AT2 receptors mRNA levels in control and AMPD males and females offspring. (B) Relative integrated density values (IDV) of AT2 receptors protein levels in control and AMPD males and females offspring. *Denotes p-value < 0.05 on two-tailed unpaired Student’s t-test. N = 5 for each group.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: As a consequence of AMPD, the present study demonstrates sexually dimorphic programming of hyperglycemia associated with changes in the pancreatic RAS in mice (Figure 9). With protein malnutrition during pregnancy, we observed intra-uterine growth restriction in the mice pups (Figure 1A). Moreover, intra-uterine growth restriction with AMPD diet was observed in both sexes, and this agrees with other studies. Of importance, we observed increased blood glucose levels with normal insulin levels in the female offspring from the AMPD group. Similar to our findings, a study in rats demonstrated that at three weeks of age, AMPD reduced insulin release after oral glucose challenge.18 Thus, it appears that glucose-stimulated insulin release is impaired in female offspring as a consequence of AMPD.

caption.p: Summary schema of the sexually dimorphic programming observed as a consequence of antenatal maternal low-protein diet (AMPD).

sec.p: To gain mechanistic insights of the developmental basis of the dysregulation of glucose metabolism as a consequence of AMPD, we examined the local pancreatic RAS. Importantly, the RAS exists not only as a systemic pathway,8 but also as a whole in various tissues and organ systems such as brain,11 lung9,12 and placenta10 that function independently. Furthermore, studies have identified the existence of pancreatic RAS and its dysregulation with a variety of pancreatic disorders.6,7 We demonstrate that with AMPD there are sexually dimorphic changes in the pancreatic RAS pathway (Figure 9). In male and female offspring from protein-restricted mice dams, AGT, renin, ACE-1 and angiotensin II were increased in the pancreas. Of interest, only in male offspring were ACE-2 and AT-2R increased significantly in response to AMPD. Importantly, in the males we did not observe an increase in blood glucose levels in the AMPD group. On the contrary, AMPD female offspring did not show an increase in ACE-2 and AT-2R, but demonstrated a significant increase in blood glucose levels. We speculate that increase in ACE-2 and AT-2 may be a factor in preventing the development of higher blood glucose in male offspring (Figure 9).

In agreement with our findings, previous reports demonstrate that pancreatic RAS is up-regulated in T2DM rodent models such as obese db/db mice19 and Zucker Diabetic Fatty Rats.20 Furthermore, RAS inhibition provided remission of T2DM in these diabetic rodent models. Moreover, inhibition of RAS prevents inflammation and fibrosis exacerbated by chronic hyperglycemia.21 Of note, a recent meta-analysis of 12 different clinical trials showed that pharmacological inhibition of the RAS protects against the onset of T2DM.13 T2DM-associated hyperglycemia also has been shown to activate the pancreas RAS.22 In the present study, although we were not able to detect renin mRNA in the pancreas, renin protein was detected. Nonetheless, other studies have demonstrated the presence of the renin mRNA in the pancreas.19,23,24

In conclusion, the present study provides evidence that AMPD can lead to alterations in the local pancreatic RAS, which may be responsible for programming of hyperglycemia in adult offspring. In our previous reports in the same mouse strain, we have demonstrated development of hypertension (Goyal and Longo, in press) and important changes in offspring gene expression in the RAS, systemic components,8 as well as locally in the placenta,25 lung9 and brain.11 Further studies will be needed, however, to elucidate the mechanisms involved in differential expression of the pancreatic RAS components in a sexually dimorphic pattern as a consequence of AMPD.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.

fn.label: Conflict of interest
fn.p: There is no conflict of interest for the conducted studies.
